column3: 1. rekening (from Dutch – used in banks and hotels), 2. akun (used for all meanings of account apart from bank account)
1. setelah (also used in Malay to indicate consecutive actions), 2. sesudah, selepas

column2: lapangan terbang ('airfield' in Indonesian; similar to Dutch vliegveld)
column3: bandar udara (loan translation of the English term, commonly abbreviated as bandara), lapangan terbang

column2: pangsapuri, rumah pangsa, rumah kondo (only for 'condominium')
column3: apartemen (influenced by Dutch appartement), rumah susun (rusun) (public housing for poor families), kondominium

column2: majlis, perhimpunan (from the root verb 'himpun' meaning 'to gather/assemble')

column3: Athena (influenced by Dutch Athene or from native Greek Athina)

column2: makcik (also used in Riau Malay dialect in Indonesia), emak saudara, ibu saudara

column3: autobiografi, otobiografi is a nonstandard spelling
otomatis (derived from Dutch pronunciation of automatisch)
fakultas (from Latin: Facultas), fakulteit (obsolete, from Dutch)
penggemar, fans informal, from English; Indonesians always use the plural form
federasi from Dutch federatie, serikat, persekutuan[39]
pemadam kebakaran (lit. fire extinguisher), branwir (from Dutch brandweer (fire defense))

column2: tingkat may be used in Indonesian to express the number of storeys/levels a building has, e.g. a 5-storey building = gedung bertingkat 5, or to emphasize British floor numbering, e.g. tingkat satu means first floor (UK), second floor (US) in both languages, aras (used to emphasize American floor numbering, e.g. aras dua = tingkat satu
column3: lantai also refers to floor as ground surface in both languages, emphasizes American floor numbering, tingkat emphasizes British floor numbering, e.g. lantai dua = tingkat satu

column2: perabot rumah, perkakas rumah (In Indonesian, perkakas means equipment)
column3: mebel from Dutch meubelen, perabot rumah tangga, furnitur
